addressleaf.section:
A copie of M
r
Bodley his l
re
to my L. Cecil 4 Ma
r
1594.

page.lettertext:
fol.173r
Maie it please y
r
good L. Amonge diverse l
res
sent from
Brussells,
& intercepted heere of late, I sent you 2
with my last of the 2 of the 26
th
of Fe
b
: and herewith a
third w
ch
was allso written by the same
Critton
to
James Tyrius
the scottish Jesuit at
Rome,
& did
not seeme to be regarded by those
t
kept the l
res
but I finde it worthe the reading for many respects
because it
doth
manifest
t
there are many brabbles
and discontentm
ts
among those of
t
nation in Bru-
ssells & elce where: &
t
they are in dispaire of good
sucesse in the enemies actions both heere & in
Fraunce
It is also easie to
ceave by
using the wordes
interla
c
sed with the figures,
t
there is matter there
signified of speciall importance; w
ch
if it can not be
deciphered by any at home, I am of opinion
t
the copie of the l
re
being sent to some man
t
is
of capacitie & emploied by y
r
L. in Brussels or
Andwerp,
if he be but acquainted with the scott
t
are there, & the factious among them, it wilbe
p
r
ntlie discovered. These
t
are here of the scottish
Nation for want of knowledge, who they are
t
are
there, & how they stand for affection one to an other
can give me no light. As touching my negoti-
ation, the returne of the deputies of
Guilders
&
Overissell,
are daily now expected, & the the
States
I am certaine, will deliver me their answere
without putting me of to a further delay. Wee
have assured intelligence from diverse places
of the enemies contries,
t
the vulgar people
every where crie openly out against their mise-
ries, shewing manifest token
t
they desire to be
joyned to the rest of this union. And as farre
as I can judge of the states inclincation, if the
motion
ceede from the other side to them, thereafter
as it is they are fully bent to entertaine it to the
best advantage of their cause. But whether
it were expedient
t
wee should strike at this
yron, while it is hotte, & be the first
t
should send
to the enemies Pro vinces
t
doth rest in deliberac
o
n
albeit I doe
ceave
t
most men are of minde
wee should
fol.173v
we should not sturre in this case but as occasions are
presented from to [us]. For this is alleaged
for it
t
they before they send to the enemie, in a matter
of
t
importance, they must first of force hereat
some have recourse to every Province, to purchace
authoritie, whereby it will be imparted to every
towne & so come abroad, amonge the people,
who as every man doubtes, may prove so over-
headlong in suche a plausible motion, as
haps
when they see itt is once sett a foote they will
violentlie thorowe, without regard to their
owne securitie. The [feare] of this humor
in the multitude doth staie them from
ceeding
as they are otherwise willing. It is
co
m
only reported
t
the enemie p
r
pareth for
the siege of
Huy,
w
ch
he will finde a very hott
& a costlie exploite. For
Haranguieres
is
the co
m
aunder is a valiant expert souldior, and
will undoubtedlie
forme as much as can be
required.
And thus I take my humble
leave. Ma
r
4 1594.
